Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Why is the cost function defined in the way that it is?
Input.posts:
After watching the first week's worth of lectures, I am stuck on one point of understanding - why is the cost function defined the way it is? Specifically, it is defined as $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1) = \frac{1}{2m}\sum_{i=1}^m (h_\theta (x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2$$ What I ask is, why is there so much complication? Realistically, we could attempt to minimize a much simpler function instead, such as $$J(\theta_0, \theta_1) = \sum_{i=1}^m |h_\theta (x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)}|$$ instead. Or is there a reason wer cannot use a simpler function? Mainly, the issue I'm having trouble with is understanding: Why we square the difference of the predicted and actual value. Why we divide the sum by $$m$$. Why we divide the sum by $$2$$. Any help is appreciated.

21
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
This may not answer all of your questions, but I hope I can answer some of your questions: 1) This thread is similar: https://class.coursera.org/ml-005/forum/thread?thread_id=68 2) the ^2 exponent is there to ensure all differences are positive, otherwise negative and positive deviations could cancel out which would not result in a good model fit. 2.5) Edit: the 'm' is to conceptually you the 'mean squared error' with the 1/m used to compute the mean. 3) the ^2 exponent vs. absolute value: both have been used, the ^2 approach gives more weight to large differences, but I'm not enough of an expert to summarize the trade-offs between the two approaches. Both probably produce reasonable results. 4) The 2 in the denominator outside the summation is there so that when the cost function is differentiated, the derivative will have a 2 in the numerator from the [ ]^2 term and so the two 2's cancel each other. 5) I think that taking the derivative of an absolute value term is messy. If so, that might explain why the ^2 is used vs. absolute value.

Input.threadtitle: Supervised learning or Unsupervised learning algorithm for Regression type problems?
Input.posts:
In regression type problem we don't need to explicitly classify data, we do not specify any information about the data as contradiction to classification type problem where we need to specify information on data(e.g spam/not spam). The learning algorithm itself predicts the output. So why does the regression type of problems are included in as problem being solved by supervised learning algorithms?
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Because you don't know the learning algorithm. You need to derive it from the available dataset. Here a simple linear equation: y = a + b * x; where a is the intercept ad b is the slope In our high school math, we know parameters a and b as well as x , so you could plug in the values to get y . In Machine Learning, we have a set of x and y, but we have no idea what a and b should be. Assuming that you know that a linear equation gives correct answer (which is a big assumption), you need to estimate those parameters from the available dataset. So in regression, what you learn is the optimal values of those parameters, and for training, you need both x and y . Those are called training dataset, and because you use such dataset for training, this is a supervised learning. Furthermore, we will learn that there is no guarantee that available dataset is actually good representation of the underlying distribution of possible values, so there is a risk of finding values for a and b that gives wrong answer for entirely new set of x and y , and how to deal with this issue.

Now suppose I were using only two parameters, theta0 and theta1, this would make theta a [2 X 1] vector. If the training set size m was = to 150, then X would be a [150 X 2] matrix and y would be a [150 x 1] vector. Now the only way I could multiply theta and X would be to do X * theta. This is the only way to get a [150 X 1] vector from which I can then subtract y. While my answer seems to be correct, doing X * theta is not quite the same as doing theta * X is it? I would be grateful for any help.....

In the lecture, when calculating y for a single X, the equation is $$\theta^TX$$, and notice that is X is a column vector. However, when doing the exercise, the X are represented by many 'row vectors'. You can try to calculate by hands, and see why 'X * theta' works.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Use transpose to make the dimensions match. Yong-Siang is correct that you can't always follow the math notations exactly, because the shape of the actual data may be different. No big deal, just apply transpose to X or theta, whichever gives you the correct dimensions to allow matrix multiplication.
